abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Primary Education Project in the
            Republic of Equatorial Guinea. The objectives of the Primary
            Education Project were: (i) to support improvements of
            primary school teaching through teacher training and the
            provision of instructional materials; (ii) to expand and
            improve the physical facilities in rural areas through
            construction and furnishing of 100 new classrooms in 50
            rural communities; and (iii) to reinforce the planning and
            implementation capabilities of the Ministry of Education and
            Science (MOES) through assistance to MOES' education
            planning division and establishment of a Project
            Implementation Unit (PIU) in the Ministry. Since its
            conception, the project was plagued by many difficulties
            including an overly complex design, lack of clear
            coordination mechanisms for co financing of certain
            components and, above all, the Government's very
            limited administrative and implementation capacity. Bank
            performance was mixed. The objectives of the project were
            consistent with the needs of the country but its design was
            flawed. The Borrower played a positive role at the
            preparation stage but failed to deliver at the
            implementation phase. The principal lessons learned from the
            project are as follows: (i) project design needs to be kept
            simple and in line with the public sector's capacity;
            (ii) the lack of Government commitment and ownership have a
            detrimental impact on all aspects of a Project; (iii) if the
            successful completion of project objectives depends on co
            financing, project appraisal must assure that this co
            financing is secure; and (iv) projects under such field
            onditions should be provided with a full complement of
            technical assistance staff and up front mobilization of
            qualified counterpart staff.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Primary Education Project aims at
            assisting the Ministry of Education (MOE) in its efforts to
            restructure basic education by implementing the new
            curricula, increasing the availability and use of teaching
            materials, improving classroom management practices,
            creating new teaching positions, training managers and
            teachers and expanding physical facilities in rural areas.
            To accomplish such objectives, the project includes such
            components as (a) revision, printing and distribution of
            mathematics, language, social studies and natural science
            textbooks for all primary school children and training of
            teachers in the use of these books; (b) improvements in
            classroom management practices; and (c) appointment of 250
            new teachers.  Further to this, the project entails (d)
            assistance to rural communities for the construction and
            furnishing of about 100 classrooms; and (e) strengthening of
            the planning and implementation capacity within MOE.  As
            part of this last component, the project finances studies
            needed to prepare the 1990-1995 development plan and the
            corresponding financial plan.
